physDesc.p: Four pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am sending you all the poem’s of Richard’s which I have, as you asked me to do. As Harriet Monroe has doubtless written you, she has accepted "Fatigues," but I had a copy made of it, so that you should not lose it from your collection, and am sending it with the others. I am awfully interested to know that Richard is to have another volume. Please send it to me when it comes out. I have not heard from him since January, which is my fault, as I have not answered his last letter. I shall do that, however, in a day or two and send it to you to forward. Do tell me what he is doing and where he is, and I cannot bear to lose touch, and now that we have no longer any anthology to get out, I am terribly afraid that we may drift apart before the end of the war brings us together again. I understand that it is impossible to leave England just now, so I do not suppose that there is any chance of your coming over at all.

I saw your mother for a few minutes at Bryn Mawr when I went down there to lecture in May, and I found her awfully sympathetic and nice. We only had a little talk, and I wished it might have been longer.

I think you will like what I say about you in my new book. It is also to be published, slightly abridged, as a review of "Sea Garden" in Brown’s "Poetry Journal," and I will send you a copy of it as soon as it comes out, and also of course the book when that appears.

I am afraid that our "Anthology" is not doing as well as the others have done. Under a separate cover, I am sending you all the clippings up to date. Fletcher’s "Lincoln" gets the most praise and next to that Flint’s "Zeppelins". The truth is the breaking out of war in this country has turned everybody’s attention away from literature for the moment. I cannot help hoping that they will turn back before long, but it is certain that there is less interest than there has been for the past two or three years. I have not advertised the "Anthology" as much as usual because Ferris Greenslet told me it would be money absolutely thrown away, and I have been waiting until the first effect of the war was past and people had settled down to the new conditions. I intend to advertise again in September in conjunction with the two earlier ones. I think, however, that the "Anthology" has really done its work, as I have already told you and as I have just written Flint. People know what Imagist work is; they know what we stand for. We have made our principles understood, and, if we differ somewhat among ourselves as to just what these principles are, why we have agreed enough to give the public a definite idea of something. As we develop, it is inevitable that we should widen a little from the original narrow path in which we walked together, and we shall probably continue to stray from right to left, following our own bents, but I cannot help thinking that we shall always have much in common. I do believe, however, that it will be better now to publish our own books, rather than any group anthology, and I think this would have been true even if the war had not made it so difficult to compile the volume. I know quite well that you people do not follow me in all my experiments, but I suppose that is inevitable, as we each become more individual we shall each depart more and more from the group ideal. Still, I feel that we shall all be more in sympathy with each other than with any other people, and that is a pleasure to me.
I wish we might meet and talk everything over; I wonder when we shall. Write some time. It will be a great disappointment if I do not hear from you, even if we have no business to transact.

I am also enclosing a money order for five dollars, which is the last of Brown’s payments on the original agreement with Richard. There may be more royalties in a year or two, and I shall keep after him and try to get some if there are any. He sent me this cheque some time ago, and I should have sent it to you, but, like everything else it got delayed.

You probably know that no sheets or plates of books published in America can now be sent to England. Constable, however, agreed to print this new "Anthology" and we had duplicate plates made here and shipped to them England on board the "Colonian". Unfortunately the boat went down, and our plates are now delighting the mermaidens. They were, however, insured, and the Constable purposes to have a new set made in England from a copy of the book which has been shipped to them from here, so it ought to come out there.

I am afraid my book will not see the light of day in England at all, as my sale over there is not so brilliant as to justify duplicate plates. Mr. George MacMillan wants me to go over and give some lectures after the war, as I have been doing here, and possibly I may, but that is too far ahead to consider.
In the mean time, there is a possibility that the book may be issued in translation in Paris, but everything is very much in the air at present.

How does it happen that you have resigned the assistant editorship of "The Egoist?" Ezra’s coming back on the paper fills me with horror, and he seems to have got in with Margaret Anderson. Her little sheet is entirely full of him. Of course Margaret Anderson’s erratic method of publication and her peregrinations to the Pacific Coast have more or less killed her contributors here. I rather think they have all left her except myself, and I certainly do not feel inclined to put anything more into her paper while the Ezra group is so prominent there. I have a theory that somehow he has raised some money and has made it worth her while to take him, although I have known Margaret Anderson to refuse offers of this sort before. If you know anything about these matters, I wish you would let me know, for I feel very much out of it here.
I shall write to you again next month, when our semi-annual royalties come in, and in the mean while, do keep me posted.
body.postscript: P.S. Do not forget that "Leave Taking" and "On the March" have been accepted by "Seven Arts," and "Fatigues" has been accepted by "Poetry."
